quote: If you're going to have a complicated story, you must work to a map; otherwise you can never make a map of it afterwards.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If you're going to have a complicated story, you must work to a map; otherwise you can never make a map of it afterwards.
summary: This quote means that if you're working on something complex, like a complicated story or a large project, it's crucial to have a clear plan or outline from the start, much like following a map. If you dive into a complicated task without a pre-existing structure or guide, it will be impossible to go back and make sense of it, organize it logically, or understand how all the pieces fit together once it's finished. Essentially, you can't create order or a clear understanding of something intricate *after* the fact if you didn't build it with a plan in mind.

quote: He raised his staff. There was a roll of thunder. The sunlight was blotted out from the eastern windows; the whole hall became suddenly dark as night. The fire faded to sullen embers. Only Gandalf could be seen, standing white and tall before the blackened hearth.

quote: But it is not your own Shire,’ said Gildor. ‘Others dwelt here before hobbits were; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more. The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But it is not your own Shire,’ said Gildor. ‘Others dwelt here before hobbits were; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more. The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.
summary: Gildor tells the hobbits that the Shire isn't truly their own exclusive home. He explains that others lived there long before hobbits, and others will live there again after hobbits are gone, meaning the hobbits are just temporary inhabitants in a much older and larger world. Despite their attempts to isolate themselves and build fences, the vast outside world is always present and cannot be kept out forever.

They express a strong liking for natural surroundings like gardens, trees, and traditional farmlands that are worked without machines. Additionally, they enjoy the simple pleasures of smoking a pipe and eating good, plain food that is fresh and not stored in a refrigerator.

quote: A good vocabulary is not acquired by reading books written according to some notion of the vocabulary of one's age group. It comes from reading books above one.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A good vocabulary is not acquired by reading books written according to some notion of the vocabulary of one's age group. It comes from reading books above one.
summary: To develop a strong vocabulary, simply reading books that are specifically written for your age group or current reading level isn't enough, as these books often stick to a limited set of words. Instead, the best way to expand your word knowledge is to challenge yourself by reading books that are slightly more advanced or complex than what you're currently comfortable with.

quote: Some believe it is only great power that can hold evil in check, but that is not what I have found. It is the small everyday deeds of ordinary folk that keep the darkness at bay. Small acts of kindness and love. Why Bilbo Baggins? Perhaps because I am afraid, and he gives me courage.

quote: Why should a man be scorned if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if, when he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Why should a man be scorned if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if, when he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls?
summary: This quote suggests that it's only natural for someone facing a difficult or restrictive situation to want to escape it and return to a better life. Furthermore, if they cannot escape, it's also natural and understandable for them to choose to think and talk about topics beyond their immediate problems and limitations, rather than constantly dwelling on their confinement. Essentially, it argues that people should not be criticized or looked down upon for seeking freedom or for finding mental relief and hope when faced with adversity.

quote:
The dragon is withered
His bones are now crumbled;
His armour is shivered,
His splendour is humbled!
Though sword shall be rusted
And throne and crown perish
With strength that men trusted
And wealth that they cherish,
Here grass is still growing,
And leaves are yet swinging,
The white water flowing,
And elves are yet singing
Come! Tra-la-la-lally!
Come back to the Valley!

The stars are far brighter
Than gems without measure,
The moon is far whiter
Than silver in treasure:
The fire is more shining
On hearth in the gloaming
Than gold won by mining,
So why go a-roaming?
O! Tra-la-la-lally
Come back to the Valley!

O! Where are you going,
So late in returning?
The river is flowing,
The stars are all burning!
O! Wither so laden,
So sad and so dreary?
Here elf and elf-maiden
Now welcome the weary
With Tra-la-la-lally
Come back to the Valley,
Tra-la-la-lally
Fa-la-la-lally
Fa-la!

summary: This poem encourages a weary traveler to return to a peaceful, natural "Valley" that offers true and lasting beauty. The speaker emphasizes that the simple beauty of stars, the moon, and a warm hearth fire is far more precious than any gems, silver, or gold. Essentially, it's a call to abandon the search for fleeting worldly treasures and find comfort, joy, and a warm welcome in the timeless, simple wonders of nature.

quote: For suddenly above him far and faint his song was taken up, and a voice answering called to him. Maedhros it was that sang amid his torment. But Fingon climbed to the foot of the precipice where his kinsman hung; and then he could go no farther, and he wept when he saw the cruel device of Morgoth. Maedhros therefore, being in anguish without hope, begged Fingon to shoot him with his bow; and Fingon strung an arrow, and bent his bow. And seeing no better hope he cried to Manwe, saying: 'O King to whom birds are dear, speed now this feathered shaft, and recall some pity for the Noldor in their need!'....Now, even as Fingon bent his bow, there flew down from the high airs Thorondor, King of Eagles, mightiest of all birds that have ever been, whose outstretched wings spanned thirty fathoms; and staying Fingon's hand he took him up, and bore him to the face of the rock where Maethros hung.

Maedhros therefore, being in anguish without hope, begged Fingon to shoot him with his bow; and Fingon strung an arrow, and bent his bow. And seeing no better hope he cried to Manwe, saying: 'O King to whom birds are dear, speed now this feathered shaft, and recall some pity for the Noldor in their need!'....Now, even as Fingon bent his bow, there flew down from the high airs Thorondor, King of Eagles, mightiest of all birds that have ever been, whose outstretched wings spanned thirty fathoms; and staying Fingon's hand he took him up, and bore him to the face of the rock where Maethros hung.
summary: Fingon found his kinsman Maedhros singing in agony, hanging from a cliff by a cruel device of Morgoth. Unable to reach him, Fingon watched as Maedhros, in despair, begged to be shot with an arrow to end his torment. Seeing no other hope, Fingon prepared his bow and prayed to Manwe for pity. However, just as he was about to fire, Thorondor, the immense King of Eagles, suddenly appeared. Thorondor prevented Fingon from shooting, instead lifting him and carrying him directly to the cliff face where Maedhros was suspended.

He took his staff in one hand and the phial in his other. When he saw that the clear light was already welling through his fingers, he thrust it into his bosom and held it against his heart. Then turning from the city of Morgul, now no more than a grey glimmer across a dark gulf, he prepared to take the upward road.
summary: Despite still feeling despair, Frodo found a deep resolve within himself, realizing his physical weakness had passed. He understood with grim determination that he absolutely had to complete his difficult task, and it didn't matter if anyone else knew about it or not. Taking his staff and the glowing phial, which he held close to his heart, he turned away from the now distant city of Morgul and prepared to continue his arduous journey upwards.

quote:
Of the Three Rings that the Elves had preserved unsullied no open word was ever spoken among the Wise, and few even of the Eldar knew where they were bestowed. Yet after the fall of Sauron their power was ever at work, and where they abode there mirth also dwelt and all things were unstained by the griefs of time. Therefore ere the Third Age was ended the Elves perceived that the Ring of Sapphire was with Elrond, in the fair valley of Rivendell, upon whose house the stars of heaven most brightly shone; whereas the Ring of Adamant was in the Land of Lórien where dwelt the Lady Galadriel. A queen she was of the woodland Elves, the wife of Celeborn of Doriath, yet she herself was of the Noldor and remembered the Day before days in Valinor, and she was the mightiest and fairest of all the Elves that remained in Middle-earth. But the Red Ring remained hidden until the end, and none save Elrond and Galadriel and Cirdan knew to whom it had been committed.

Thus it was that in two domains the bliss and beauty of the Elves remained still undiminished while that Age endured: in Imladris; and in Lothlórien, the hidden land between Celebrant and Anduin, where the trees bore flowers of gold and no Orc or evil thing dared ever come. Yet many voices were heard among the Elves foreboding that, if Sauron should come again, then either he would find the Ruling Ring that was lost, or at the best his enemies would discover it and destroy it; but in either chance the powers of the Three must then fail and all things maintained by them must fade, and so the Elves should pass into the twilight and the Dominion of Men begin. And so indeed it has since befallen: the One and the Seven and the Nine are destroyed; and the Three have passed away, and with them the Third Age is ended, and the Tales of the Eldar in Middle-earth draw to then-close.

quote:
But I have so little of any of these things! You are wise and powerful. Will you not take the Ring?"

His eyes flashed and his face was lit as by a fire within. "Do not tempt me! For I do not wish to become like the Dark Lord himself. The wish to wield it would be too great for my strength. I shall have such need of it. Great perils lie before me.

quote:
But this is terrible!’ cried Frodo. ‘Far worse than the worst that I imagined from your hints and warnings. O Gandalf, best of friends, what am I to do? For now I am really afraid. What am I to do? What a pity that Bilbo did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!’
‘Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his ownership of the Ring so. With Pity.’
‘I am sorry,’ said Frodo. ‘But I am frightened; and I do not feel any pity for Gollum.’
‘You have not seen him,’ Gandalf broke in.
‘No, and I don’t want to,’ said Frodo. I can’t understand you. Do you mean to say that you, and the Elves, have let him live on after all those horrible deeds? Now at any rate he is as bad as an Orc, and just an enemy. He deserves death.’
‘Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.

- But no living man am I! You look upon a woman. Éowyn I am, Éomund's daughter. You stand between me and my lord and kin. Begone, if you be not deathless! For living or dark undead, I will smite you if you touch him.
summary: This quote describes a tense confrontation where a sword is drawn. A powerful, arrogant foe boasts that no "living man" can stop them. However, the person challenging them, revealed to be the woman Éowyn, bravely declares that she is not a man, thereby sidestepping the foe's boast. She defiantly states her name and her resolve to protect her lord and family, threatening to strike down the enemy if they dare touch him, regardless of whether the foe is alive or undead.

quote: Now goblins are cruel, wicked, and bad-hearted. They make no beautiful things, but they make many clever ones.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Now goblins are cruel, wicked, and bad-hearted. They make no beautiful things, but they make many clever ones.
summary: This quote explains that goblins are inherently mean, evil, and unkind creatures. Because of their bad nature, they are incapable of creating anything beautiful or artistic. However, it also highlights that despite their lack of beauty, goblins are very intelligent and resourceful, capable of making many clever and ingenious things, though these creations likely serve their wicked purposes rather than good ones.
